Hi Liz,
After the realization that Akamai was sharing one cache among all of the redirected sub-domains, and the resulting problems regarding users being unexpectedly redirected, we removed this behaviour last week.
Kirsten & Russ are currently managing Akamai being reconfigured to have one cache per sub-domain in order to achieve the required behaviour.
I believe this is being set up on the staging Akamai instance first but I don't know how far they have got (I am waiting until I hear from Kirsten before re-enabling the redirects).
It should be re-enabled on production before the end of the week (I would hope an awful lot sooner, but much of it is out of Kitsite's hands!).
Kieran

Thanks, Kieran!

Hopefully Kirsten will have a follow-up for me soon.

I am presuming that Kirsten has got in touch, saying that these domains should now be live?
Kieran

I haven’t seen an email from my inbox from her, but that could just be because I have a LOT of emails still to go through.

However, I just tried youngleaders and it still is asking me for a password to access the staging server??

I think they would like to turn the FTP server off next Friday.

Hi Kirsten,
We will aim for this, but I have been having some problems connecting; I think it might be SSL version incompatibility so it might take a little while to fix. Please can we we request that FTP isn't switched off until we've given our explicit acknowledgement that we're ready to go?
Thanks,
Kieran

Actually ... it would make it a lot quicker for us to implement if we could use public key authentication rather than username/password authentication. Is this in any way feasible?
Thanks,
Kieran
It’s not something we can quickly implement or that we’re keen to do. If you really have no way around it then we’ll do another impact assessment and take it from there.
I have told GDP not to turn off the FTP server until we tell them it is OK to do so.

Hi Kirsten,
We are now using the SFTP server.
If possible I would rather wait until Monday before switching off the FTP server, to give us a good test run first.
Kieran
Set to 0.8 days as I had to install new perl modules, manually making them, testing, etc.
Are we good to switch this off on Monday?

Hi Kirsten,
As far as we are concerned, the files are being retrieved successfully and the events are being uploaded to the website. For a definitive opinion, it might be worth contacting the Festival team (to double-check that their additions/changes have been making it through to the live site). However as long as GDP assure you that they are pushing all changes to the SFTP server in the same way as they were pushing to the FTP server then I am sure all is ok!
Sorry for the ambiguous response. Basically, I'm saying it all looks good from where we're sitting!
Kieran
Thanks

Do you mean the first two of the three production webservers? (if so, can I ask why the third isn't being patched? perhaps it already has been?)
Or do you mean the two staging servers?

Yes, I mean the first two web servers.

If we haven’t asked for any other servers, it means the YUM report for them was empty.

No, BT wouldn’t test the patches on staging. We’ve always patched the specific servers we’ve asked for and it’ll mean that the staging are up to date already if I haven’t asked you about them now.

A meeting of musical cultures featuring some of the biggest names in UK urban music.

Urban Classic is a meeting of musical cultures, bringing together the BBC Symphony Orchestra with leading artists from the UK's urban music scene. As part of the Music Nation weekend, this event will be the first performance of new arrangements by Ayanna Witter-Johnson and Jason Yarde. For Urban Classic, the BBC Symphony Orchestra will be conducted by Jules Buckley, fresh from his collaboration with Basement Jaxx and the Metropole Orchestra, where he is Principal Guest Conductor.

Part of the BBC's Music Nation, uniting orchestras, musical groups, choirs and concert halls all over the UK.

David.

Please can we be sent the link to circulate to partners before this is live.

If this copy needs to be edited please can you confirm word count and we can send over revised copy.


The Barking Bathhouse, Something & Son

CREATE in partnership with LB Barking & Dagenham and the Mayor of London.

CREATE has commissioned Something & Son - the design practice behind the hugely
successful FARM:shop in Dalston - to design and build The Barking Bathhouse. Focusing on
wellbeing the Bathhouse will experiment in the latest health and beauty ideas and technologies
with an overall aim of helping people feel happy and relaxed this summer.
The pavilion will combine a spa with a bar where the public will be able to sip healthy cocktails
and smoothies under a canopy of growing cucumbers and sunbathe amongst piles of industrial
debris. After soaking up vitamins and being pampered with unusual treatments visitors will
sweat it out then cool down in the engine room - a sustainable steam room and pioneering 'dry
ice' chiller. The purpose-built design will take influence from the 20th century working man's
bathhouse, ultra modern spa treatments and Barking's industrial heritage to bring a new
dimension to Barking town centre.

www.createlondon.org

Anna Doyle
Producer

Hello (CC Wahome),

I'm afraid we have no control over whether "nationwide" events are included in the search.
We just display the results that a returned from the GDP search API.
I think at some point they might have been instructed to return nationwide events, even if a specific location is being searched on (I presume the reasoning being that BBC Three is available in Bradford and is thus accessible to residents of Bradford).
If you want the events to be removed from the search then GDP will need to be (re-)instructed, You might - instead - want to consider adding a prominent logo to indicate "nationwide" events?

In case you're wondering, we (Kitsite) can't simply omit results that are "nationwide" events, as then the totals and the paging (which we obtain from the GDP API) would all be out.

Please let us know how you would like to proceed.

Kind regards,

Kieran
Ok thanks a lot. I have flagged this to Wahome and we will just change the order of the search results

comments.value: The British Olympic Association is opening a museum in the Olympic park in 2014.  Some time before the end of the year they will want to export an archive of stories and images from the london 2012 website. They may end up getting most of this from D3. None of our content will include anything after the switchover and I think D3 are sucking in a lot of our old archive content. However, they do want to get our advice and there may be an opportunity for some consultancy work from them at some point. Contact: Steve Stines.

Hi Steve,

Good speaking with you yesterday,

Just to confirm what we spoke about:

- The london2102.com content will be held in our CMS/Database till the end of this year when LOCOG's CMS licence expires.

- We are happy to hold onto content in the CMS post this date, but depending on timescales the there may be some small additional costs involved in us keeping this data post that date.

- The key editorial content (news, blogs, photos, press releases, publications) are all exportable as structured XML (I have attached an example)

- The majority of assets (images/pdfs) used by or linked to from the above content can be supplied as a zip files (the names/paths will match up the the above XML export)

- The majority of key content is tagged with meta data from both a fixed taxonomy (ie. sport/venue) and non-fixed folksonomy (ie. sustainability, transport)

- We can supply example of the fixed taxonomies (I have attached sports and venues)

- We already (as part of the move to the games time website) have various export API's setup for exporting the above key content. Although we will need to setup new accounts and API keys for yourself (or your developers) to access these API's. I expect you will also require a small amount of handholding / help in understanding the format of these API's (as they were a one off there is no documentation for them). Although we would expect the effort required to get you up to speed / for us to make any necessary changes to suit you import/requirements to be modest (for example we worked with the games time developers to migrate the current content to the games time website in just over a week). It probably makes sense for us to agree on a rough allowance of days towards to end of the summer with regards to this work (let me know if you would like me to make an extremely rough estimate now for budgetary purposes, say for 5 days work on helping you manage the export, although do bear in mind that this may change, up or down, once we understand your exact needs in more detail)

In terms of other things that may (or may not) be required (as I understood it, it was only the content you are interested in and not snapshots of the site as fully formed thing). 

- Content that falls outside of key content (news, blogs, photos, press releases, publications) ie. the "about us" or "sponsors" page.
There is a large amount of content that falls outside of what we have termed above as 'key content' this ranges from  the "about us" page to the "young leaders" or "get involved" sections.
All this content is available for export in a similar format to news, blogs etc. but may be much less well formed (ie. a news story always has a date, author, summary paragraph etc.) but a hub page for  "young leaders" may juts be a few paragraphs of text and/or a list of team members. The good news is that it will all be available if required, the downside is we may need to write some additional export API's for you and spend a little longer working with you so that you can make use/sense of this data (although our export format is fairly self describing).

- Images
I assume LOOCG have the rights to all the images (that they have received via Getty) and this is simply handed onto you as part of the legacy agreement.

- Festival site
I am assuming that the content from the festival site (festival.london2012.com) will not make us the museum site, do let me know if my assumption is wrong as although the site can be exported it may require slightly more effort in terms of creating that export.

- Switch off of the website vs the CMS
It may be the case that LOCOG IT decide to switch of the website prior to us switching off the CMS. The current 2012 CMS instance will stay live till at least the end of the year (as we manage that part). However the BT web infrastructure hosting the current site may be switched off post the games in September (waiting on confirmation on this either way). This shouldn't present a problem as all the content will still be held in our CMS/database. Where it may impact you is if you wish to view/navigate the current website in preparation for the Museum site (in the worse case we could republish the site elsewhere for you to view it if required).

- A complete (working) 'snapshot' of the website (looking as it does now) as static HTML. 
Although it is not possible to supply a fully working copy of the site as static html, due to there being sections of the site that will not work standalone as static HTML (ie. the search). We could supply a copy of the HTML+PHP code that currently resides on the server if required. If this is required it will need to be requested prior to the decommissioning of the live BT servers (which I believe is the end of the year although could be as soon as the end of games). Another avenue is to spider the current website now, with an offline website scrapping application and/or talk to Akamai (who current cache the website) to see if they can supply a 'snapshot' of their cache. 

- "Snapshots in time" of the website 
We could not be able to supply these, however waybackmachine/the internet archive has snapshots of the site back to the bid site in 2004 :-) 
It may be worth speaking to these guys in terms of what you could do re. snapshots of the site? This would also cover the above requirement of a static copy of the site.
http://wayback.archive.org/web/*/http://www.london2012.com

In summary, all the content is available as XML, some (news, blogs) is highly structured and tagged other content is more freeform (and therefore may be harder to re-use in an automated way). The CMS and DB will be available to export from till the end of the year (but we are happy to keep it live longer, we just need to discuss timescales/costs if this is the case). There may be a modest cost in terms of us helping you manage the export (happy to give an estimate, but we should resume the conversation later this year). In terms of 'snapshots' or access to the site as it current stands (ie. as a complete website not in terms of content) you may be best to talk to the guys at Akamai or the internet archive (as they have already crawled and archived the site, including snapshots over time).

Hope that all helps, feel free to send over any other questions..

If I don't speak to you before have a great summer, enjoy the games and hopefully speak to you later in the year.

Many thanks

Jamie

From: Amy Prosser [mailto:Amy.Prosser@twofour.co.uk]
Sent: 23 March 2012 14:35
To: Tom Price-Stephens
Cc: Richard Ward
Subject: GeoBlocking of Video in MF

Hi Tom

I just tried to give you a quick call to update you on the GeoBlocking of the single video within MediaFreedom.

This has been implemented and released for you but we will need kitsite to make some amends before this will work as it should do.
At the moment, we are only being returned the kitsite IP when videos are requested from us and this makes it impossible for us to tell where the end user is coming from. This should be a simple change from the kitsite end to return the end user IP address to us because the ability to receive this info already exists within MF. As soon as this change is made, MF is configured and ready to deliver that video to IP addresses from the UK only.

In addition to this, Kitsite will also need to make a slight change to show the ‘this video cannot be displayed in your region’ message – at the moment when videos are blocked they just seem to buffer for ages as kitsite are not currently configured to receive and display this.

One final point to note is that we currently have the rule set up to allow connections from a UK address plus anything that is not recognised by the GeoIP service. The amount of IP’s that are not known on the GeoIP database is very very minimal but if you would like us to add ‘unrecognised addresses’ to the block list then please let us know.

I think that covers everything but I will be in the office for at least the next couple of hours if you would like me to clarify any of this further and also if you have an opportunity to send that email to Rich so I can help clear up anything he is unsure of.

If I don’t hear from you before, I’d like to wish you all the very best for games time and in your career beyond locog – it has been an absolute pleasure working with you and I do hope we can keep in touch.

Amy

Marking as high.

Hi Tom,

(jump to last line if you want and then read back)

Rhetorical question :-) Surely you want to do the geo-blocking at the point the video is served to the user and not at the point we retrieve the details of the video from TwoFour four (via the CMS) which is prior to us even publishing the video page (ie. it happens once when a new video is created/uploaded into the CMS).

The point at which we the video is served is when the page is loaded into the users browser (ie. by that point we have no control over it).
http://www.london2012.com/videos/2012/olympic-torchbearers-to-get-their-moment-to-shine.php

The call for the video is simple a block of (client side) HTML/Javascript that makes a call to a Javascript file and a SWF file on twoFours server (view the source and scroll down to the line "var url = 'http://players.mediafreedom")

The request for the video will come from the users browser / the users IP address, rather than from the live web servers (or even less so the CMS server).

I am a bit confused, Amy seems to be describing the point at which we call TwoFour to get the details of the video (ie. title / thumbnail etc.) but at the point that the video is displayed to the user we simply call two four (or rather the users browser calls TwoFour) and passes in a programme ID.

I would have thought the sensible way to handle this is for TwoFour to serve a dummy video / static message, in place of the video for GeoBlocked users? That seems tends to be the common way to handle GeoBlocking of videos (namely restrict the stream, rather than the code that retrieves the url/path to the stream).

In short I am not sure we need to be involved for TwoFour to geo-block a video, surely they just can restrict the stream based on the users IP? the request for the video will come from the users browser and hence their IP address (not ours).

Hope that makes sense...

Jamie

Hi Tuesday,

When you say "online brochure" are you referring to a PDF or something else?

if it's a PDF, you can upload the file anywhere in the CMS, although I have created a new folder at the top level called 'Documents' you probably want to use.

You can then link to the PDF just like you would any other page, ie. use the link tool, search for it and then select it. If you want to link from test then (assuming that text field accepts 'rich text' ie. bold/italics/links and you can edit it in the CMS then you should be able to highlight some text and link that word or text).

Jamie

Great, many thanks. Yes it would be PDF format.
What about a feature like this? http://www.eif.co.uk/2012-brochure. Is this possible?

Also, I’ve flagged a cache issue that GDP has raised because there are updated copy that are not appearing on the website.
Many thanks,

Tuesday

Hi Tuesday.

Do you have any budget? :-)

That's a serious question! We could of course setup something like the EIF site, but it would:

- Fall outside of the template set we currently have (so would require some additional deign/build work)
- If you wanted the embed viewer, require us (or you) to setup an account with a PDF viewing/hosting service like Issuu [ http://issuu.com ] 

It would probably involve 1 or 2 days work depending on the amount of design/build work involved (for a new template) and whether you needed us to handle all the work setting up Issuu (or a similar service). 

You may also have to pay to use the Pro version of Issuu to the adverts (although I think thse only appear if you navigate to the publication via the Issue site and not if you are simply embedding the publication like on the EIF site).

We could simplify it somewhat by just having a image of the cover that you click to get the PDF, rather than using something like the Issuu embedded "viewer", although that would probably still require some design/build work.

Let me know how you want to progress.

Jamie

Hi Jamie

Let me get back to you on this. Honestly, I think we will go for the simplified version but I’ll pitch this just in case.

Tuesday

Hi Jamie

Could you give me a price quotation on this?

Best regards,

Tuesday
For something exactly like the EIF page ie. including an embedded Issuu viewer?
Yes please!

Hi Tuesday,

Please find costs attached.

If you'd like us to proceed would you be able to supply a PO number.

Many thanks

Jamie


2012 Festival - setup of online pdf viewer.pdf

Thanks I’ve sent this to our operations head and will get back to you on this.

Tuesday

Hi Jamie

Looks like this will be approved. I will let you know as soon as I get clearance.

Tuesday

Hi Jamie

We are raising a PO for this. How early do you need the PDF brochure and in what format?

Tuesday

Thanks Tuesday,

To be honest it's probably the last thing we'll need, although if you have an early copy that would be great as we can get everything setup with the correct size.

Just as a PDF is fine.

ps. if you have the option of reducing the size of the embedded images (it may be called "save for web use" or similar) please select it as we won't need the PDF to be at a 'print ready' resolution / size. But dont' worry too much, we can probably do that bit for you if required.

Jamie

Thanks Jamie

Just have one quick question.

On cache issue – hope you got the forwarded message from me with email thread from Lucie of GDP.
There had been some updates on some events that are not appearing on the Festival website- GDP said this is CMS issue and not theirs. I wonder if this has something to do with just my account –? My colleague has been loading new events and he could see his updates after an hour.
Could you kindly take a look at this for me please?

Also just a sort of a warning, as we are loading more events this week and next, hope its ok to be bombarding you all with emails if there are technical questions and issues. We just want to have a fully working website on 26 April.

Many thanks.

Hi Tuesday,

- "Hope you got the forwarded message from me with email thread from Lucie of GDP"

No I havent' seen it? Do you mind forwarding to me direct jamie@kitsite.com

I assume what they mean is that they (think) they are sending the event to us in the feed (but they are still not appearing). If they make edits to the same events as you do the edits appear on the site? (please test this on a different event than the one you send us as an example, or else we may start getting confused)

Also do any of your updated and/or new events appear, or are none of them (updates and/or new) appearing?

thanks

Jamie

Hello, there's a minor but urgent change requested on the Festival site to
mask the events count to the right of the search bar. Reason: there's a
major marketing campaign kicking off on Thursday Apr 26 (final Festival
commissions/launch), and the messaging is around thousands of events
(performances), which doesn't sit well with the database definition of
events count displayed so conspicuously on the site (300+).

Could you kindly comment out the div for the events-counter across all
templates before Thursday morning? Thank you.

Its gone from the live site now including the mobile site.

[ hidden via Css, i hope that's ok for this purpose, there are JavaScript dependencies that i don't want to break ]
Lars that works and is perfect for the purpose - thanks.

From: Andy Watkins
Sent: 20 April 2012 11:41
To: 'Domenico Ventura'; Tom Price-Stephens; 'Kieran Topping'
Cc: Steve Wiseall; Kavita Kapoor; Jamie Unwin
Subject: RE: Roadrunner extract



Hi Domenico,



Well, this has been a fun one to investigate! My findings as follows.



1. Ballygalley and Malborough are misspelt communities in Roadrunner.
Not sure how we’ve not spotted them before, but I’ve corrected in our
macro so the updated extract attached should have the correct values
of Ballygally and Marlborough. Similarly, I’ve changed Nottingham (a)
to just Nottingham.



2. Denham and Shaldon are genuine communities but missing from the
Regions mapping. Denham needs to be added to London, and Shaldon needs
to be added to the South West.



3. The others are all ‘moments’, which are generally short diversions
to take in a famous place or landmark. In the rush to get the last
release out we agreed these would not be accessible via the
region/communities search (they still appear in searches by name and
date), but we’ll need to address this on the GTW. We’ll either assign
them to the nearest actual community, using the macro, or include them
in the communities list. I’ll confirm as soon as I can but I think the
latter option is probably the more palatable.



Kieran, could you apply the change in point 2 to the current TB search
page, and process the updated extract attached?



Steve, I’ve converted Kieran’s json file containing the communities to
regions mapping into a spreadsheet, attached. You might find this
useful for testing.



Thanks all,

Andy
